sen.j: 丁未約条（ていびやくじょう）とは、1547年に朝鮮王朝と対馬の宗氏の間で結ばれた来航者取締規則のこと。
sen.e: Teibi Yakujo was regulations relating to the control of visitor to Japan which was agreed between Yi-Dynasty and the So clan in Tsushima in 1547.
Teibi Yakujo were regulations relating to the control of visitors to Japan which were agreed between the Yi-Dynasty and the So clan in Tsushima in 1547.

sen.j: 1544年に発生した蛇梁倭変により、1512年に宗氏と朝鮮王朝の間で締結された壬申約条は破棄され、日本国王使（室町幕府使節）および大内氏・少弐氏の使節を除き、日本からの通交（外交を兼ねた貿易）は禁じられた。
sen.e: In the Daryo (saryanjin) wahen (koshin no hen) occurred in 1544, jinshin Yakujo concluded between the So clan and Yi-Dynasty in 1512 was denunciated; thereafter, trading (trade concurrently with diplomacy visit) from Japan was inhibited except for King of Japan envoy (the Muromachi bakufu envoy) and the envoys from the Ouchi clan and the Shoni clan.

sen.e: In the saryan wahen (Coup of Shinryo IWAYA) which occurred in 1544, the Jinshin Yakujo concluded between the So clan and the Yi-Dynasty in 1512 was denounced; thereafter, trading (trade concurrent with a diplomacy visit) from Japan was inhibited except for the King of Japan envoy (the Muromachi bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun] envoy) and the envoys from the Ouchi clan and the Shoni clan.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 日朝貿易を経済的基盤としていた宗氏は事態の打開を図り、1547年に偽日本国王使を派遣した結果、締結されたのが丁未約条である。
sen.e: It was Teibi Yakujo that was concluded when the So clan, which was economically based on Japan-Korea trade, managed to effect a breakthrough in the situation and dispatched a pseudo King of Japan envoy in 1547.

The Teibi Yakujo that was concluded when the So clan, who were economically dependent on Japan-Korea trade, managed to effect a breakthrough in the situation and a pseudo King of Japan envoy was dispatched in 1547.

sen.j: 三浦の乱の講和条約である壬申約条では、島主歳遣船（対馬から通交のため毎年派遣される貿易船）を50隻から25隻に削減、多くの深処倭（対馬以外の日本人のこと）名義の歳遣船の停止等、宗氏に通交の抑制を強いるものであった。
sen.e: Jinshin yakujo, which was a peace treaty ending the Sanpo no ran (Sanpo Incidence), forced the So clan to restrain dispatching of trade ships such as to force to reduce toshu saikensen (Annual Tribute Ships to Korea from the Lord of Tsushima; trade ships annually dispatched from Tsushima for trading and diplomatic visit) from 50 to 25, and stop dispatching saikensen under the name of many shimuchowe (Japanese people other than the residents of Tsushima), and the like.

The Jinshin Yakujo, which was a peace treaty ending the Sanpo no ran (Sanpo Incident), forced the So clan to restrain the dispatching of trade ships so as to force the reduction of toshu saikensen (Annual Tribute Ships to Korea from the Lord of Tsushima, and trade ships annually dispatched from Tsushima for trading and diplomatic visits) from 50 to 25, and to stop dispatching saikensen under the name of many shimuchowe (Japanese people other than the residents of Tsushima).

The Jinshin Yakujo, which was a peace treaty ending the Sanpo War, forced the So clan to restrain the dispatching of trade ships so as to force the reduction of toshu saikensen (Annual Tribute Ships to Korea from the Lord of Tsushima, and trade ships annually dispatched from Tsushima for trading and diplomatic visits) from 50 to 25, and to stop dispatching saikensen under the name of many shimuchowe (Japanese people other than the residents of Tsushima).

sen.j: その後の度重なる交渉により、島主歳遣船は30隻にまで回復していたが、丁未約条では再び25隻に削減される。
sen.e: Through repeated negotiations thereafter, the toshu saikensen recovered to 30, but, they were reduced to 25 again by Teibi Yakujo.
Through repeated negotiations thereafter, the toshu saikensen increased in number to 30, but, they were reduced to 25 again by the Teibi Yakujo.

sen.j: またそれ以外に、50年以前の受図書人（朝鮮王朝により通交許可を受けた者）・受職人（朝鮮王朝より官位を受けた者）の通交権の停止、入港場を釜山浦・薺浦（慶尚南道鎮海市）の二港から釜山浦一港に削減、加徳島以西に来泊する者は倭寇とみなす等、壬申約条よりもさらに通交の抑制を進める厳しい内容となっていた。
sen.e: Besides, Teibi Yakujo was further severe than Jinshin yakujo in that it stopped the right to trade for toso receiver (those who received permission to trade by Yi-Dynasty) and Jushikijin (those who received official rank from Yi-Dynasty) more than 50 years ago, reduced the entry ports from two of Busan Inlet and Jepo (South Gyeongsang Province, Jinhae City) to one of Busan Inlet, took those who stayed Gadokdo Island or further west places as wako, and the like.

In addition to this, the Teibi Yakujo was greater in severity than the Jinshin Yakujo in that it stopped the right to trade for a toso receiver (those who received permission to trade from the Yi-Dynasty) and jushikijin (those who received an official rank from the Yi-Dynasty) more than 50 years ago, reduced the entry ports from both Busan Inlet and Jepo (South Gyeongsang Province, Jinhae City) to one of only Busan Inlet, and took those who stayed on Gadokdo Island or further west places as wako.

In addition to this, the Teibi Yakujo was greater in severity than the Jinshin Yakujo in that it stopped the right to trade for Jutoshonin (Japanese given Korean government evidence to be granted special privileges in trading) and Jushokunin (Japanese given Korean government post who has special technique such as healing art) before 1550, reduced the entry ports from both Busan Inlet and Jepo (Jinhae City, Gyeongsang-namdo Prefecture) to one of only Busan Inlet, and took those who stayed on Gadokdo Island or further west places as wako.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。「50年以前」の意味が確認できず、「1550年以前」としています。

sen.j: 丁未約条締結後、宗氏は通交抑制の緩和を求める交渉を繰り返し、1557年に丁巳約条が締結されることとなる。
sen.e: After Teibi Yakujo had concluded, the So clan repeated negotiations for requesting appeasement of restraining the trading and diplomacy visit, and in 1557, Teishi Yakujo was concluded.

After the Teibi Yakujo was concluded, the So clan continued negotiations for requesting a reduction in restrictions relating to trading and diplomacy visits, and in 1557 the Teishi Yakujo was concluded.
